subject: statistics
title: Logistic Regression: Binary Classification
contentHtml:
Logistic regression is a fundamental concept in machine learning and statistics that enables binary classification tasks.

In simple terms, it's a way to predict the probability of an event occurring (e.g., 0 or 1) based on one or more input features. The core idea is to model the relationship between these inputs and the target variable using a sigmoid function.
intuition: Think of logistic regression as a 'probability gatekeeper.' It takes in inputs and outputs the probability that an event occurs, which can be used to make predictions or classify new data.
commonMistakes: Not understanding the difference between logistic regression and linear regression

subject: statistics
title: Logistic Regression: Binary Classification
contentHtml:
Logistic regression is a fundamental concept in machine learning and statistics that allows us to model binary classification problems.

In logistic regression, we use the logit function to map the input features to a probability between 0 and 1. This probability represents the likelihood of an instance belonging to one class or the other.
intuition: The key insight is that logistic regression uses the logit function to model the relationship between the input features and the probability of belonging to one class or the other.
realWorldApplications: Predicting customer churn in a telecom company
commonMistakes: Confusing logistic regression with linear regression
Not understanding the importance of the logit function

subject: statistics
title: Logistic Regression
contentHtml:
Logistic regression is a fundamental concept in statistical modeling that allows us to predict binary outcomes (0/1, yes/no) based on one or more predictor variables.

The key idea is to model the probability of the positive class using a sigmoid function, which maps any real-valued number to a value between 0 and 1. This enables us to estimate the odds ratio, which represents the change in the log-odds for a one-unit change in the predictor.
intuition: Logistic regression is a way to model the probability of a binary outcome based on one or more predictor variables. It's like asking, 'What's the chance that someone will buy a product given their age and income?'
commonMistakes: Not understanding the difference between odds ratio and log-odds
Using logistic regression for non-binary outcomes
